A SUGGESTION FOR THE VACATION.
summer vacation, which during
THEthelong
past few years has become universal
in our colleges, is not without its disadvantages.
To the instructors, and to the more matured
students, it is an inestimable benefit: it enables
them to carry out plans of study and of literary
production, for which the busy routine of the
working months of the year affords little room.
Those who are dependent, in whole or in part,
upon their own exertions find it helpful toward
the solving of the problem of self support,
since the old-time custom of "teaching school"
for a few weeks in the winter is no longer
practicable, and remunerative employment is
more easily had in the summer. The favored
few who enjoy the privilege of a trip abroad
are not likely to have the time heavy upon
their hands, and the unfortunates, with
"conditions" to be made up, possess a boon
in this prolonged opportunity, for which it
may be feared, they are not always duly
grateful.
But how is it with the majority of the
younger students in our colleges—those who
are not under compulsion to earn money, who
are not in arrears with their studies, who are
not sent to Europe, but who stay quietly at
home during all or most of the time, with
nothing in particular to engage their attention?
No doubt there are a thousand profitable
uses to which the superabundant leisure of
these three or four months might be put, and,
if the young collegian developes in the right
way, he will, a few years hence, be well aware
of them, but, at. present, his tastes are undeveloped, his plans of life are not formed, and

110 .111

No. 17

—supposing him to be a normal youth—the
"faculty for idlmess" is one of his most
salient characteristics. Very possibly he will
form sundry good resolutions, and he may go
so far a to enter with great enthusiasm upon
some elaborate scheme of self improvement,
but it may be pretty confidently predicted that
in the absence of any outside requirement, his
commendable purposes will lead to very moderate results.
Why do not the Summer Camps, which
provide so useful combination of work and
play for boys, furnish a hint to those who
have outgrown the schoolboy stage? Why may
not a party of college undergraduates, of congenial tasts and habits, who are agreed in
liking sport, and good fellowship, and out-door
life, and also in wishing to turn their holiday
to some serious account, establish themselves
in an environment such as the directors of
these camps provide for their pupils, and put
themselves, of their own will, under a regimen
combining work and deversion in such proportion as may seem to them good? A party
properly constituted for this purpose ought,
like the English ministry "of all the talents,"
to include persons of diverse gifts; practical
ability such as is required for the business and
financial management of the enterprise, experience in camping, interest in athletic sports,
musical and other social accomplishments,
competent scholarship in the various subjects
to be studied—these are some of the qualifications, one or more of which each member of the
party should be expected to possess. A company thus variously endowed, living a free,
unconventional, out-of-door life, for a series of
weeks, under self imposed rules sufficiently
strict to prevent mere aimlessness, could not

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

fail to secure a delightful recreation, and, at
the same time, to accomplish substantial results. If any of them should—in this single
particular—resemble Lord Macaulay, whose
biographer tells us that he "could neither
swim, nor row, nor drive, nor skate, nor shoot,
that he "seldom crossed a saddle and never
willingly," that the only exercise in which he
could be said to have excelled was that of
"threading crowded streets with his eyes fixed
on a book," this indifference to badly accom_
plishments could hardly survive such an op_
portunity of acquiring them. Those who
have never learned to observe the aspects of
nature, who cannot distinguish one tree, or
flower, or bird-note from another—would have
their eyes opened to a new world.
A plan of this sort could be carried into
effect without large expense. A Johns Hop_
kins Summer Camp, conducted in the right
way, might become a permanent institution.
—E. H. GRIFYIN.

A GOOD-BYE WORD FROM PRESIDENT
GILMAN.
I AM very glad that the note that I promised
to write to the NIMS-LETTER, at the close
of the session, is one of cheer.
The Trustees, yesterday, by a unanimous
vote, elected as President of the Johns Hopkins
University, our honored colleague and friend,
Professor Remsen, who has been a member of
the Faculty since the opening of the University
in 1876. His distinction as a chemist is recognized by all who are specialists in his chosen
field. His ability as a teacher has placed him
in the front rank among the members of the
Academic Staff. His readiness and directness
as a lecturer and speaker have given him
prominence before the public. Still greater
renown has come from his position as Editor
of the American Journal of Chemistry, and as
a writer of books on chemistry, which translated and reprinted are used in Germany,
France, Japan and England.
But he has
stronger claims than these upon our confidences
and regard. He is devoted to the University,
is considerate, friendly, sympathetic, punctual,

energetic, faithful, learned, and wise. For all
these reasons we may be sure that he will
prove to be a most acceptable administrator in
the leadership of a growing and complex
institution.
It is with mingled pain and pleasure that I
give up the post to which I was invited when
President of the University of California at
the end of the year 1874:—pain at the severance of so many pleasant relations; pleasure
that I give the helm to a pilot so trustworthy.
Other opportunities will undoubtedly occur
for the review of the past twenty-five years,
so I will not dwell upon the past.
One of the infelicities of the presidential
office is the necessary absorption of the incumbent in administrative and business details.
He cannot have the same relations with the
great body of students, that a professor can
have with the classes that he teaches. I have
tried to overcome this obstacle, and to keep
acquainted with as large a number of the
students as I could personally reach. I wish I
had done more, for among all the memories
of a prolonged academic life, there are none
more precious than the tokens of appreciation
and gratitude which sometimes reach me from
those who have been here enrolled as undergraduates.
I believe that the University will soon enter
upon a new era, and I hope that the college
within the university will share tn the prosperity.
June 4, 1901.
DANIEL C. GILMAN.

Twenty-fifth Academic year in the
THE
life of the Johns Hopkins University has
come to an eventful close. It has been a year
of changes, growth, and development. It has
market an era in the University's career; next
October will begin a new epoch. After a service of twenty-five years as head of the Johns
Hopkins, President Daniel Coit Gilman will
retire, and the twenty-sixth collegiate year
will be ushed in by his successor, Dr. Ira
Remsen. Furthermore, a bright future is in
store for the University. The hopes of past
years seem shortly to be realized, Hopkins will
have a new home and better opportunities will
then be afforded for growth. "Homewood" is
the goal of our ambitions, but in order to attain it we must receive assistance from our
friends, the well-wishers of Hopkins. Much
of the work accomplished by the members of
the faculty in their various departments has
been of international importance. But the
year has not been without its misfortunes : the
death of Prof. Henry A. Rowland deprived
America of her greatest physicist, and by the
resignation of Dr. Herbert B. Adams, we lost
the head of our historical department. These
places will be occupied in the future by professors Wood and Vincent, respectively.

Passing to the undergraduate body, we note
developement and success in every line of
athletic work, a full recapitulation of which is
given on another page in this, issue. The
Musical Clubs have had a most successful
year, the Public Debate was splendidly contested, and this year's "Hullabaloo" proved
excellent. In all departments scholarship has
maintained it's usual high plane, and now that
the year is over, we may look back and say
"Well done."
sr ger
HE selection of Professor Remsen, of the
department of chemistry and one of the
first professors on the Hopkins Faculty, as
President of the University is in every respect
a most happy one.
From the student's standpoint, there is
probably no one who could fill the fatherly
place of "Uncle Dan" so well as Dr. Remsen.
Dr. Gilman always took a more than presidential interest in the welfare of his students, and
it was this characteristic that made him so popular with the fellows. From what the student
body has so far experienced in their intercourse with Prof. Remsen, they have every
reason to believe that in the new president
they have a man who, besides posessing executive ability of the highest order, and other
qualities necessary for such a high position,
will always have the true interest of the
students at heart, forgetting, forgiving, and
punishing as they deserve.
Everybody knows what Dr. Gilman has
done for Hopkins; how he, given leave to
model a University on his own ideas, has built
up in twenty-five years, an institution that
already stands towering in the midst of the
American colleges, and in many respects
reaches the high. plane of culture of the old
German universities: but only the students
can know what he has done for them. He
has always been their friend. In time of
victory he has shared their joys; and in time
of trouble he has always given them justice.
President Remsen has prospects of widening
the scope of work of the University and of
extending its influence even farther than at
present; and the University could enter on its

THE NEWS-LETTER,
second quarter under no better leadership than
President Remsen. From the student body
the NEWS-LTTER extends to the new president sincere hopes of the closest relationship,
and pledges of support in all his undertakings.
ww
URING the past year the NF,WS-LETTER has
endeavored to keep pace with the progress
made by other Hopkins Institutions. Whether
or not we have accomplished this, we leave
our readers to judge. At all events, we have
expended much work in trying to produce a
representative Hopkins publication, and we
extend our thanks to the student body for
their interest, encouragement, and. support.
Dr. Gilman contributes to this issue a farewell
to the students. To Dr. Griffin we are
indebted for an article of interest containing
profitable vacation hints. Both of these gentlemen are warm friends of the I\TEwsLirrrnit, and feel a vital interest in its
welfare,

MUSICAL CLUBS.
last meeting of the Musical Clubs was
HE
held last Friday, at 12 in., in McCoy
Hall. Manager Bird read his report for the
past year and stated that the Clubs had over
one hundred and fifty dollars in bank. He
then made a motion that one hundred dollars
of this be appropriated to found a training
table for the athletic teams. The want of
such a table has been felt for many years, and
the Musical Clubs were glad that they might
be so instrumental in founding one.
The Clubs then moved that the president,
manager, leaders, and assistant managers
be thanked for their untiring zeal in behalf of
the organizations, and that appropriate testimonials be drawn up and presented to them.
The Clubs also decided to give Manager Bird
some fit gift as a token of the appreciation of
his work during the past year. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year:
President, Andrew R. Bird; Manager, nen
C. Hill; Assistant Manager, Robinson C.
Pagon. Leadei of Glee Club, Howard Eager;
of the Mandolin Club, Walter Krager, and of
the Banjo Club, Charles Marshall. Then
came a few short speeches after which the
Clubs closed the most successful year in their
history with nine rousing "Hullabaloos."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
After a little rest athletic work began again.
The Track and Field team began to get in its
"good knocks." At the set of Baltimore
Athletic Club games, at the Fifth Regiment
Armory, our boys simply walked away with
everything in sight. These games revealed
the fact that there was much good material
among the new men, and that our brilliant
record of last year would be equalled, if not
excelled, again this year.
At Georgetown a fair share of honors
"came our way," and our own games at
the armory was a repetition of our walkover
at the B. A. C. games.
From the University of Pennsylvania our
Relay Team brought another banner to the
trophy room. And at the Intercollegiate
games, things again were with us.
The title of"Champions" was lost by the
Lacrosse team this year, but the work done by
the men is indeed a thing to be proud of.
The season opened with a victory over the
University of Pennsylvania. Then followed
victories over our old-time rivals, the invincible Crescent Athletic Club, College of the City
of New York, Columbia, and Harvard. But
our downfall came when we went to Swarthmore. But even in this defeat there was
honor, for, as Coach Maddren remarked after
the game, we were beaten by a team with
superior ability.
Baseball, too, was revived this year, and the
championship won for Black and Blue. Western Maryland forfeited its game, and St. John's
was defeated.
Following is the summary of the games of
the season and their scores:

Hopkins will open the foot-ball season next
fall with brighter prospects than ever before.
Regular training will begin September 17th.,
and it is the intention of the Athletic Association to introduce two incalculable improvements—the first of which is a training table
for the entire squad, and the second is a firstclass professional coach. Under such conditions as these we should be able to bring out
a larger squad than ever before, and develope
from it a team that will again carry off the
Maryland Inter-collegiate Championship. All
men who have ever played foot-ball, who
desire to play foot-ball, or who have patriotism
for Black and Blue and can show it by trying
to play foot-ball, are urged to come out at
the beginning of the season, as the results of
the season's work depend as much upon the
"scrub" as upon the 'Varsity. Capt. Gillespie
will return to Baltimore early in September
and begin work.

FRESHMAN PRIMER.
See the lacrosse stick! I wonder whether
it is hard? Let us find out. Now Johnnie,
protrude your mug. So! Swish! Biff! Bangi
K— Flop! ? ? ? Yes it must be hard. Here,
you Miller, pick up those two teeth of Johnnie's
and endeavor to gather up those chips from
his smeller and his block. And by all means,
do not let the gory swish-swash fall on Johnnie's new pants and shoes; the Lacrosse Association will make him cough up for them or
will lay their Fists Upon His Caution Money.

See the Corpulent Goal-Keeper. I wonder
whether he can Stop a Shot. Shoot the
Lacrosse Ball swiftly upon his Corporation.
Crack! Ping! Where is the Ball? Assimilated by the Superfluity of Obesity. Shocking!
WWW
See the Lanky man. He gallops laboriously
with the ball. The stubby man heaves to.
He places his stocky shoulder lovingly within
Lanky's slats.
Hear the jarring sound!
Lanky's foundations become weak. Jrrr-r-r-r-!
Crash! Shorty sits upon Lanky's neck. How
indiscreet! Wonder what he's thinking of.
See the boy. He is falling asleep. Chemistry is so soothing. Hear him snore! Oh! Oh!
See the fly. He alights upon the nether side
of the boy's mug. See the fly hurdle the bridge
of the boy's smeller. Wasn't that s'lovely?
He alights upon the bay window of the boy's
ear. He buzzes softly, "I'd Leave Ma'
Ha—." Squash! The fly is squelched?
See the pretty goozulum on the boy's ear.
Careless fly!

HORACE S. WHITMAN, Senior and SubFreshman Class president, has his initial in
yellow to commemorate his steady work during
four years on the 'Varsity Track and Football
Teams. He will seek new honors at the
University of Maryland Law School.

The Football team and Athletic Board are
both grateful to the Clubs for such substantial
pecuniary assistance, coming as it does, when
the football team contemplates some innovations along coaching and training-table lines.
At the final meeting of the Athletic Board,
Friday, June 7th, a resolution was passed,
thanking the Clubs for the appropriation.

A SUGGESTION FOR THE VACATION.
summer vacation, which during
THEthelong
past few years has become universal
in our colleges, is not without its disadvantages.
To the instructors, and to the more matured
students, it is an inestimable benefit: it enables
them to carry out plans of study and of literary
production, for which the busy routine of the
working months of the year affords little room.
Those who are dependent, in whole or in part,
upon their own exertions find it helpful toward
the solving of the problem of self support,
since the old-time custom of "teaching school"
for a few weeks in the winter is no longer
practicable, and remunerative employment is
more easily had in the summer. The favored
few who enjoy the privilege of a trip abroad
are not likely to have the time heavy upon
their hands, and the unfortunates, with
"conditions" to be made up, possess a boon
in this prolonged opportunity, for which it
may be feared, they are not always duly
grateful.
But how is it with the majority of the
younger students in our colleges—those who
are not under compulsion to earn money, who
are not in arrears with their studies, who are
not sent to Europe, but who stay quietly at
home during all or most of the time, with
nothing in particular to engage their attention?
No doubt there are a thousand profitable
uses to which the superabundant leisure of
these three or four months might be put, and,
if the young collegian developes in the right
way, he will, a few years hence, be well aware
of them, but, at. present, his tastes are undeveloped, his plans of life are not formed, and

110 .111

No. 17

—supposing him to be a normal youth—the
"faculty for idlmess" is one of his most
salient characteristics. Very possibly he will
form sundry good resolutions, and he may go
so far a to enter with great enthusiasm upon
some elaborate scheme of self improvement,
but it may be pretty confidently predicted that
in the absence of any outside requirement, his
commendable purposes will lead to very moderate results.
Why do not the Summer Camps, which
provide so useful combination of work and
play for boys, furnish a hint to those who
have outgrown the schoolboy stage? Why may
not a party of college undergraduates, of congenial tasts and habits, who are agreed in
liking sport, and good fellowship, and out-door
life, and also in wishing to turn their holiday
to some serious account, establish themselves
in an environment such as the directors of
these camps provide for their pupils, and put
themselves, of their own will, under a regimen
combining work and deversion in such proportion as may seem to them good? A party
properly constituted for this purpose ought,
like the English ministry "of all the talents,"
to include persons of diverse gifts; practical
ability such as is required for the business and
financial management of the enterprise, experience in camping, interest in athletic sports,
musical and other social accomplishments,
competent scholarship in the various subjects
to be studied—these are some of the qualifications, one or more of which each member of the
party should be expected to possess. A company thus variously endowed, living a free,
unconventional, out-of-door life, for a series of
weeks, under self imposed rules sufficiently
strict to prevent mere aimlessness, could not

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

fail to secure a delightful recreation, and, at
the same time, to accomplish substantial results. If any of them should—in this single
particular—resemble Lord Macaulay, whose
biographer tells us that he "could neither
swim, nor row, nor drive, nor skate, nor shoot,
that he "seldom crossed a saddle and never
willingly," that the only exercise in which he
could be said to have excelled was that of
"threading crowded streets with his eyes fixed
on a book," this indifference to badly accom_
plishments could hardly survive such an op_
portunity of acquiring them. Those who
have never learned to observe the aspects of
nature, who cannot distinguish one tree, or
flower, or bird-note from another—would have
their eyes opened to a new world.
A plan of this sort could be carried into
effect without large expense. A Johns Hop_
kins Summer Camp, conducted in the right
way, might become a permanent institution.
—E. H. GRIFYIN.

A GOOD-BYE WORD FROM PRESIDENT
GILMAN.
I AM very glad that the note that I promised
to write to the NIMS-LETTER, at the close
of the session, is one of cheer.
The Trustees, yesterday, by a unanimous
vote, elected as President of the Johns Hopkins
University, our honored colleague and friend,
Professor Remsen, who has been a member of
the Faculty since the opening of the University
in 1876. His distinction as a chemist is recognized by all who are specialists in his chosen
field. His ability as a teacher has placed him
in the front rank among the members of the
Academic Staff. His readiness and directness
as a lecturer and speaker have given him
prominence before the public. Still greater
renown has come from his position as Editor
of the American Journal of Chemistry, and as
a writer of books on chemistry, which translated and reprinted are used in Germany,
France, Japan and England.
But he has
stronger claims than these upon our confidences
and regard. He is devoted to the University,
is considerate, friendly, sympathetic, punctual,

energetic, faithful, learned, and wise. For all
these reasons we may be sure that he will
prove to be a most acceptable administrator in
the leadership of a growing and complex
institution.
It is with mingled pain and pleasure that I
give up the post to which I was invited when
President of the University of California at
the end of the year 1874:—pain at the severance of so many pleasant relations; pleasure
that I give the helm to a pilot so trustworthy.
Other opportunities will undoubtedly occur
for the review of the past twenty-five years,
so I will not dwell upon the past.
One of the infelicities of the presidential
office is the necessary absorption of the incumbent in administrative and business details.
He cannot have the same relations with the
great body of students, that a professor can
have with the classes that he teaches. I have
tried to overcome this obstacle, and to keep
acquainted with as large a number of the
students as I could personally reach. I wish I
had done more, for among all the memories
of a prolonged academic life, there are none
more precious than the tokens of appreciation
and gratitude which sometimes reach me from
those who have been here enrolled as undergraduates.
I believe that the University will soon enter
upon a new era, and I hope that the college
within the university will share tn the prosperity.
June 4, 1901.
DANIEL C. GILMAN.

Twenty-fifth Academic year in the
THE
life of the Johns Hopkins University has
come to an eventful close. It has been a year
of changes, growth, and development. It has
market an era in the University's career; next
October will begin a new epoch. After a service of twenty-five years as head of the Johns
Hopkins, President Daniel Coit Gilman will
retire, and the twenty-sixth collegiate year
will be ushed in by his successor, Dr. Ira
Remsen. Furthermore, a bright future is in
store for the University. The hopes of past
years seem shortly to be realized, Hopkins will
have a new home and better opportunities will
then be afforded for growth. "Homewood" is
the goal of our ambitions, but in order to attain it we must receive assistance from our
friends, the well-wishers of Hopkins. Much
of the work accomplished by the members of
the faculty in their various departments has
been of international importance. But the
year has not been without its misfortunes : the
death of Prof. Henry A. Rowland deprived
America of her greatest physicist, and by the
resignation of Dr. Herbert B. Adams, we lost
the head of our historical department. These
places will be occupied in the future by professors Wood and Vincent, respectively.

Passing to the undergraduate body, we note
developement and success in every line of
athletic work, a full recapitulation of which is
given on another page in this, issue. The
Musical Clubs have had a most successful
year, the Public Debate was splendidly contested, and this year's "Hullabaloo" proved
excellent. In all departments scholarship has
maintained it's usual high plane, and now that
the year is over, we may look back and say
"Well done."
sr ger
HE selection of Professor Remsen, of the
department of chemistry and one of the
first professors on the Hopkins Faculty, as
President of the University is in every respect
a most happy one.
From the student's standpoint, there is
probably no one who could fill the fatherly
place of "Uncle Dan" so well as Dr. Remsen.
Dr. Gilman always took a more than presidential interest in the welfare of his students, and
it was this characteristic that made him so popular with the fellows. From what the student
body has so far experienced in their intercourse with Prof. Remsen, they have every
reason to believe that in the new president
they have a man who, besides posessing executive ability of the highest order, and other
qualities necessary for such a high position,
will always have the true interest of the
students at heart, forgetting, forgiving, and
punishing as they deserve.
Everybody knows what Dr. Gilman has
done for Hopkins; how he, given leave to
model a University on his own ideas, has built
up in twenty-five years, an institution that
already stands towering in the midst of the
American colleges, and in many respects
reaches the high. plane of culture of the old
German universities: but only the students
can know what he has done for them. He
has always been their friend. In time of
victory he has shared their joys; and in time
of trouble he has always given them justice.
President Remsen has prospects of widening
the scope of work of the University and of
extending its influence even farther than at
present; and the University could enter on its

THE NEWS-LETTER,
second quarter under no better leadership than
President Remsen. From the student body
the NEWS-LTTER extends to the new president sincere hopes of the closest relationship,
and pledges of support in all his undertakings.
ww
URING the past year the NF,WS-LETTER has
endeavored to keep pace with the progress
made by other Hopkins Institutions. Whether
or not we have accomplished this, we leave
our readers to judge. At all events, we have
expended much work in trying to produce a
representative Hopkins publication, and we
extend our thanks to the student body for
their interest, encouragement, and. support.
Dr. Gilman contributes to this issue a farewell
to the students. To Dr. Griffin we are
indebted for an article of interest containing
profitable vacation hints. Both of these gentlemen are warm friends of the I\TEwsLirrrnit, and feel a vital interest in its
welfare,

MUSICAL CLUBS.
last meeting of the Musical Clubs was
HE
held last Friday, at 12 in., in McCoy
Hall. Manager Bird read his report for the
past year and stated that the Clubs had over
one hundred and fifty dollars in bank. He
then made a motion that one hundred dollars
of this be appropriated to found a training
table for the athletic teams. The want of
such a table has been felt for many years, and
the Musical Clubs were glad that they might
be so instrumental in founding one.
The Clubs then moved that the president,
manager, leaders, and assistant managers
be thanked for their untiring zeal in behalf of
the organizations, and that appropriate testimonials be drawn up and presented to them.
The Clubs also decided to give Manager Bird
some fit gift as a token of the appreciation of
his work during the past year. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year:
President, Andrew R. Bird; Manager, nen
C. Hill; Assistant Manager, Robinson C.
Pagon. Leadei of Glee Club, Howard Eager;
of the Mandolin Club, Walter Krager, and of
the Banjo Club, Charles Marshall. Then
came a few short speeches after which the
Clubs closed the most successful year in their
history with nine rousing "Hullabaloos."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
After a little rest athletic work began again.
The Track and Field team began to get in its
"good knocks." At the set of Baltimore
Athletic Club games, at the Fifth Regiment
Armory, our boys simply walked away with
everything in sight. These games revealed
the fact that there was much good material
among the new men, and that our brilliant
record of last year would be equalled, if not
excelled, again this year.
At Georgetown a fair share of honors
"came our way," and our own games at
the armory was a repetition of our walkover
at the B. A. C. games.
From the University of Pennsylvania our
Relay Team brought another banner to the
trophy room. And at the Intercollegiate
games, things again were with us.
The title of"Champions" was lost by the
Lacrosse team this year, but the work done by
the men is indeed a thing to be proud of.
The season opened with a victory over the
University of Pennsylvania. Then followed
victories over our old-time rivals, the invincible Crescent Athletic Club, College of the City
of New York, Columbia, and Harvard. But
our downfall came when we went to Swarthmore. But even in this defeat there was
honor, for, as Coach Maddren remarked after
the game, we were beaten by a team with
superior ability.
Baseball, too, was revived this year, and the
championship won for Black and Blue. Western Maryland forfeited its game, and St. John's
was defeated.
Following is the summary of the games of
the season and their scores:

Hopkins will open the foot-ball season next
fall with brighter prospects than ever before.
Regular training will begin September 17th.,
and it is the intention of the Athletic Association to introduce two incalculable improvements—the first of which is a training table
for the entire squad, and the second is a firstclass professional coach. Under such conditions as these we should be able to bring out
a larger squad than ever before, and develope
from it a team that will again carry off the
Maryland Inter-collegiate Championship. All
men who have ever played foot-ball, who
desire to play foot-ball, or who have patriotism
for Black and Blue and can show it by trying
to play foot-ball, are urged to come out at
the beginning of the season, as the results of
the season's work depend as much upon the
"scrub" as upon the 'Varsity. Capt. Gillespie
will return to Baltimore early in September
and begin work.

FRESHMAN PRIMER.
See the lacrosse stick! I wonder whether
it is hard? Let us find out. Now Johnnie,
protrude your mug. So! Swish! Biff! Bangi
K— Flop! ? ? ? Yes it must be hard. Here,
you Miller, pick up those two teeth of Johnnie's
and endeavor to gather up those chips from
his smeller and his block. And by all means,
do not let the gory swish-swash fall on Johnnie's new pants and shoes; the Lacrosse Association will make him cough up for them or
will lay their Fists Upon His Caution Money.

See the Corpulent Goal-Keeper. I wonder
whether he can Stop a Shot. Shoot the
Lacrosse Ball swiftly upon his Corporation.
Crack! Ping! Where is the Ball? Assimilated by the Superfluity of Obesity. Shocking!
WWW
See the Lanky man. He gallops laboriously
with the ball. The stubby man heaves to.
He places his stocky shoulder lovingly within
Lanky's slats.
Hear the jarring sound!
Lanky's foundations become weak. Jrrr-r-r-r-!
Crash! Shorty sits upon Lanky's neck. How
indiscreet! Wonder what he's thinking of.
See the boy. He is falling asleep. Chemistry is so soothing. Hear him snore! Oh! Oh!
See the fly. He alights upon the nether side
of the boy's mug. See the fly hurdle the bridge
of the boy's smeller. Wasn't that s'lovely?
He alights upon the bay window of the boy's
ear. He buzzes softly, "I'd Leave Ma'
Ha—." Squash! The fly is squelched?
See the pretty goozulum on the boy's ear.
Careless fly!

thanking the Clubs for the appropriation.
